statement.tex: \text{Find the second order derivative of the }\\ \text{function }e^x . \sin 5x.

step.context: \text{What do you understand by the second}\\ \text{order derivative of a function f(x)?}
\text{which one of following the correct way to }\\ \text{find } \dfrac{d{f(x)}}{dx}\text{ where $f(x) = e^x . \sin 5x$}?
step.tex:
\text{First, finding the first order derivative}\\ \begin{align} \dfrac{d(f(x))}{dx} &= \dfrac{d(e^x . \sin 5x)}{dx}\\ &=\underbrace{\frac{d(e^x )}{dx} . \frac{d(\sin 5x)}{dx}}_{\text{Product Rule}}\\
&=5 e^x . \cos 5x \end{align}\\
step.reason: \text{We have used Product Rule here.It's a}\\ \text{standard formula.Review it if you got this}\\ \text{wrong.}\\

step.context: \text{Is the following the correct way to }\\ \text{find } \dfrac{d^2(f(x))}{dx^2}?
step.tex: \dfrac{d^2(f (x))}{dx^2} = \dfrac{d(f^{\prime}(x))}{dx}= \dfrac{d(e^x . \sin 5x + 5 e^x . \cos 5x )}{dx}\\ \qquad\qquad= \frac{d(e^x)}{dx} . \sin 5x +e^x . \frac{d(\sin 5x)}{dx}+\\ \qquad\qquad\qquad 5.\frac{d(e^x)}{dx}.\cos 5x+5.e^x . \frac{d(\cos 5x)}{dx}\\ = e^x . \sin 5x + 5. e^x .\cos 5x + 5 .e^x \cos 5x - 25 . e^x . \sin 5x \\ = 10 e^x \cos 5x -24 e^x \sin 5x\\ =2 e^x (5 \cos 5x - 12 \sin 5x)
